Title: Introduction to Static Arrays
Starter: Think of a way to store multiple numbers, like test scores. How would you do it without arrays? Now, how can arrays help?
Description: Students will learn to declare and initialize static arrays in their chosen language (Java, C++, Python, or C#) using a language-appropriate IDE. The focus is on array syntax and structure. The submittable artifact is a source file (e.g., .java, .cpp, .py, .cs) creating and printing a static array of test scores.

Title: Accessing and Modifying Arrays
Concepts: Accessing elements by index, modifying elements
Starter: If you have an array of numbers, how do you change the third number?
Description: Students will practice accessing and modifying array elements by index in their chosen language’s IDE. The focus is on array manipulation techniques. The submittable artifact is a source file modifying specific array elements.

Title: Input and Output with Arrays
Concepts: Reading input into arrays, printing arrays
Starter: How would you ask the user to enter 5 numbers and store them in an array?
Description: The lesson covers reading user input into arrays and displaying their contents in a chosen language (Java, C++, Python, or C#). Students will create a program to handle array I/O. The submittable artifact is a source file accepting and outputting an array of user inputs.

Title: Iterating Through Arrays
Starter: Why might you need to go through each element of an array one by one?
Description: Students will explore loop-based array iteration in their chosen language, using for and while loops in an IDE. The focus is on processing array data efficiently. The submittable artifact is a source file that iterates and processes an array.

Title: Sorting Arrays
Concepts: Basic sorting techniques, like bubble sort
Starter: How would you arrange a list of numbers in order from smallest to largest?
Description: The lesson introduces sorting algorithms like bubble sort in a student-chosen language (Java, C++, Python, or C#). Students will implement a sorting algorithm in their IDE. The submittable artifact is a source file that sorts an array.

Title: Introduction to Dynamic Arrays
Starter: What if you don't know how many elements you need in advance? How can dynamic arrays help?
Description: Students will learn about dynamic arrays (e.g., ArrayList in Java, vector in C++, list in Python, List in C#) and their flexibility in their chosen language’s IDE. The focus is on dynamic data structures. The submittable artifact is a source file creating and adding elements to a dynamic array.

Title: Modifying Dynamic Arrays
Starter: How would you add a new item to a dynamic list, like adding a new friend to a contact list?
Description: The lesson covers adding and removing elements in dynamic arrays in a chosen language, with practical examples in an IDE. Students will modify a dynamic array. The submittable artifact is a source file performing add/remove operations.

Title: Operations on Dynamic Arrays
Starter: Why might you need to search for an element in a dynamic array?
Description: Students will practice searching and iterating dynamic arrays in their chosen language, focusing on efficiency in an IDE. The focus is on advanced array operations. The submittable artifact is a source file that searches a dynamic array.

Title: Introduction to Strings
Starter: How is a string like a sequence of characters, like your name?
Description: The lesson introduces strings as sequences of characters in a student-chosen language (Java, C++, Python, or C#), covering declaration and initialization in an IDE. Students will manipulate strings in code. The submittable artifact is a source file creating and printing strings.

Title: String Comparison and Length
Starter: How would you check if two words are the same, like "cat" and "dog"?
Description: Students will learn to compare strings and find their lengths in their chosen language’s IDE, using string functions. The focus is on string properties. The submittable artifact is a source file comparing two strings and computing their lengths.

Title: String Operations: Copy and Concatenate
Starter: How would you combine your first and last name into one string?
Description: The lesson covers string copying and concatenation in a chosen language, with hands-on exercises in an IDE. Students will write code to combine strings. The submittable artifact is a source file that copies and concatenates strings.

Title: Advanced String Operations
Starter: How would you find a word inside a sentence, like "the" in "the cat"?
Description: Students will explore advanced string operations like substring location and insertion in their chosen language’s IDE. The focus is on string manipulation. The submittable artifact is a source file performing substring operations.

Title: Understanding Scope
Concepts: Local vs global variables, function scope
Starter: If you have a variable inside a function, can you use it outside? Why or why not?
Description: The lesson introduces variable scope in a student-chosen language, comparing local and global variables in functions within an IDE. Students will write code demonstrating scope. The submittable artifact is a source file with local and global variables.

Title: Declaring and Accessing Variables
Starter: Where should you declare a variable if you need it in multiple functions?
Description: Students will practice declaring and accessing variables across different scopes in their chosen language’s IDE. The focus is on scope management. The submittable artifact is a source file demonstrating variable access across functions.

Title: Functions and Parameters
Concepts: Define functions with parameters, understand arguments
Starter: Think of a recipe: what are the ingredients, and how are they like function parameters?
Description: The lesson covers defining functions with parameters in a chosen language, focusing on argument passing in an IDE. Students will write parameterized functions. The submittable artifact is a source file with a function using parameters.

Title: Functions with Return Values
Starter: What does a function return if it has no return statement?
Description: Students will learn to create functions with return values in their chosen language, emphasizing output handling in an IDE. The focus is on function outputs. The submittable artifact is a source file with a function returning a value.

Title: Default Parameters in Functions
Starter: How can default parameters make functions more flexible?
Description: The lesson introduces default parameters in a student-chosen language, showing their use in flexible function design within an IDE. Students will write functions with defaults. The submittable artifact is a source file using default parameters.

Title: Functional Decomposition
Concepts: Identify redundant code, abstract into functions
Starter: Code cleanup: Highlight redundant code in a sample program, discuss how to simplify.
Description: Students will learn functional decomposition to simplify code by creating reusable functions in their chosen language’s IDE. The focus is on code modularity. The submittable artifact is a refactored source file with decomposed functions.

Title: Characteristics of Well-Defined Functions
Starter: Why is it important for functions to be easy to read and maintain?
Description: The lesson covers characteristics of well-defined functions in a chosen language, emphasizing readability and maintainability. Students will analyze function quality in an IDE. The submittable artifact is a written critique of a function’s design, saved as a text file.

Title: Functions Review
Concepts: Review scope, parameters, return values, exceptions
Starter: Flashcard review: Match function concepts to definitions in pairs.
Description: Students will review function concepts in their chosen language through interactive exercises and coding practice in an IDE. The focus is on reinforcing Strand 3 skills. The submittable artifact is a source file with function examples and a completed review worksheet.

Title: Using Built-in Classes
Starter: Think of a car: what can you do with a car object, like drive or honk?
Description: The lesson introduces built-in classes in a student-chosen language, focusing on object instantiation and method calls in an IDE. Students will use a built-in class in code. The submittable artifact is a source file using a built-in class.

Title: Data Members and Member Functions
Concepts: Use data members, call member functions
Starter: How are data members like properties of an object, like a car's color?
Description: Students will explore data members and member functions in object-oriented programming within their chosen language’s IDE. The focus is on object properties. The submittable artifact is a source file accessing object data members.

Title: Creating User-Defined Classes
Concepts: Create classes, use data members, constructors
Starter: How would you create a class for a student, with name and grade?
Description: The lesson covers creating user-defined classes with constructors and data members in a chosen language’s IDE. Students will design a custom class. The submittable artifact is a source file defining a user-defined class.

Title: Constructors and Member Functions
Starter: Why do we need a constructor when creating a class?
Description: Students will learn to define constructors and member functions for custom classes in their chosen language’s IDE. The focus is on class implementation. The submittable artifact is a source file with a class and constructor.

Title: OOP Review
Starter: Group discussion: What are the key differences between classes and objects?
Description: The lesson reviews object-oriented programming concepts in a student-chosen language through discussion and coding in an IDE. Students will reinforce class knowledge. The submittable artifact is a concept map of OOP principles, saved as a text or image file.

Title: Introduction to File Handling
Concepts: Create, store data in sequential files
Starter: How would you save a list of names to a file for later use?
Description: Students will learn to create and write to sequential files in their chosen language, focusing on data persistence in an IDE. The lesson includes file I/O coding. The submittable artifact is a source file that writes data to a file.

Title: Reading and Writing Files
Starter: How would you read data from a file and display it?
Description: The lesson covers reading and updating file data in a chosen language, with practical file I/O exercises in an IDE. Students will manipulate file contents. The submittable artifact is a source file that reads and updates a file.

Title: File Operations
Starter: What happens if you try to read from a file that doesn't exist?
Description: Students will explore advanced file operations, including error handling for file access, in their chosen language’s IDE. The focus is on robust file management. The submittable artifact is a source file with file error handling.

Title: Code Comprehension: Tracing
Starter: Follow the flow: Trace a simple program and predict its output.
Description: The lesson focuses on tracing code execution in a student-chosen language to understand program flow. Students will practice tracing exercises in an IDE. The submittable artifact is a trace table for a given program, saved as a text file.

Title: Debugging with IDEs
Concepts: Use IDEs for debugging, identify errors
Starter: Error detective: Identify errors in a sample code snippet, categorize them.
Description: Students will learn to use IDE debugging tools in their chosen language to identify and fix errors. The focus is on debugging techniques. The submittable artifact is a debugged source file with error annotations.

Title: Testing for Robustness
Concepts: Test code for edge cases, ensure reliability
Starter: How would you test a program to make sure it handles invalid inputs?
Description: The lesson covers testing code for robustness in a chosen language, focusing on edge cases in an IDE. Students will create test cases. The submittable artifact is a test plan with five edge case tests, saved as a text file.

Title: Project Planning
Starter: What kind of program do you want to create? What features should it have?
Description: Students will plan a programming project in their chosen language, defining specifications and data structures in an IDE. The focus is on project design. The submittable artifact is a project specification document, saved as a text file.

Title: Designing the Project
Starter: Let's sketch out the steps your program will take.
Description: The lesson focuses on designing project algorithms using pseudocode and diagrams for a project in a chosen language. Students will create a project blueprint. The submittable artifact is a pseudocode and UML diagram set, saved as a text or image file.

Title: Implementing the Project
Starter: Code studio: Build, test, and peer review projects.
Description: Students will implement and test their project in their chosen language’s IDE, applying Strand 6 concepts. The focus is on coding and documentation. The submittable artifact is the project source file and documentation.

Title: Teamwork in Projects
Starter: Team role play: Assign roles like leader, coder, and discuss responsibilities.
Description: The lesson emphasizes teamwork in project development, with role assignments and coordination for a project in a chosen language. Students will simulate team dynamics. The submittable artifact is a team task division plan, saved as a text file.

Title: Ethics in Software Development
Starter: Have you heard of any software that caused problems because it wasn't reliable? What happened?
Description: Students will explore software reliability and its societal impact through case studies, using examples from their chosen language. The focus is on ethical programming. The submittable artifact is a case study analysis, saved as a text file.

Title: Security and Privacy
Starter: How can software protect user data, like passwords?
Description: The lesson covers security and privacy in software developed in a chosen language, with discussions on data protection. Students will analyze security practices. The submittable artifact is a written plan for securing user data, saved as a text file.

Title: Automation and Society
Starter: Discuss: How does automation affect jobs, both positively and negatively?
Description: Students will examine automation’s societal effects in the context of their chosen language, debating its pros and cons. The focus is on ethical considerations. The submittable artifact is a debate position paper on automation, saved as a text file.

Title: Careers in Programming
Concepts: Different roles in a programming team
Starter: What kind of job would you like to have in the tech industry? Why?
Description: The lesson explores programming careers, focusing on team roles like analyst and developer, with examples from Java, C++, Python, or C# projects. Students will research a role. The submittable artifact is a one-page career profile, saved as a text file.

Title: Trends and Pathways
Concepts: Investigate trends, career pathways in programming
Starter: Trend debate: Is AI programming a boon or a risk for future careers?
Description: Students will investigate programming trends and career pathways in Java, C++, Python, or C#, discussing future opportunities. The focus is on industry trends. The submittable artifact is a presentation on a programming trend, saved as a presentation file.
